utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Can you tell me what brought you in here today?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Sure, I've been feeling very short of breath for the past, uh, two weeks, but even before that, I started feeling a little bit short of breath and I can't stop coughing and it just feels like it's really hard for me to breathe.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, so this started two weeks ago?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, it started two weeks ago.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and you're also coughing?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and how long have you been coughing for?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: The same amount of time, it started about, maybe three weeks ago, I started coughing more, um, but now it's worse.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and what kind of cough are you having? Is it a wet cough or a dry cough?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: It's definitely wet. My phlegm looks green.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and how long have you noticed it being green?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: It's been like that for the past two weeks.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and before that, were you having coughing as well?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, before that I was still coughing but not as much.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, uhm, and was there anything that happened, uh, did you get sick at all recently, or were you in contact with anyone who was sick?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, not that I know of.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, any kind of fevers at all?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, no fevers.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. Have you noticed any kind of, uh, coughing up blood or blood tinged sputum at all?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uhm no not that, no blood.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and how much sputum are you bringing up in an average day now?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uhm, I'm bringing up about, I'd say it would fill like two, two of my palms, like the inside of my palm.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. Alright, and is your coughing like constant or does it come and go?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: It's pretty constant now.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. And have you had at all any kind of, uh, fevers or anything like that?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No fevers.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and how about your shortness of breath? Is that, when does that happen? Is it mainly with exercise and exertion, or can it happen even when you're just going on about your day?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uhm, its, uh, ok, its more with exertion, but right now even at rest, I'm coughing and feeling short of breath.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. And are you feeling at all any kind of, uh, chest tightness or pain?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, yeah, some chest tightness.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: And is that mainly when you're coughing and short of breath or, uhm, at other times as well?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uhm, other times as well.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. Are you having any other, any other like, can you describe your chest pain a little bit? Is it kind of a pressure pain or is it a sharp pain, aching pain? How would you describe it?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uhm, I would say it's a, uh, it's a tightness in my chest. And it feels, I guess throbbing or achy?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and does this pain, uhm, move to anywhere else or does it just stay in your chest?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, it just stays in my chest.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, have you been feeling dizzy or have you fainted at all?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Have you been feeling increased sweating and confusion? Anything like that?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, have you felt your heart racing and anything like that?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. Alright, and is there anything that makes your symptoms better or worse?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uhm, I guess activity makes it worse, un, and like cold air, things like that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. And other than that, have you recently at all traveled outside of the country or outside of the province?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, no. No, not recently.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, now are you having any wheezing at all?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uhm, some wheezing, yeah.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. And any kind of headaches or nausea or vomiting.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, nothing like that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and any fevers or chills.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Ah, nope, nothing like that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any night sweats?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Ah, sometimes I feel sweaty, but that's just with the shortness of breath.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and how long does your shortness of breath usually last?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: It lasts about, uh, I don't know, I kind of feel short of breath all the time, but when it's really bad, it lasts about five-ten minutes and then it goes back to like my normal shortness of breath.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. And has this happened to you before?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uhm no, I don't think so.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Like not, not this bad, I've always had some shortness of breath but nothing like this.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. And , uh, do you have any kind of diarrhea or constipation?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uhm, no nothing like that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, how about fatigue?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, I feel fatigued.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and is that just about today or is it, do you think it's because of your shortness of breath?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, it's probably cause of my shortness of breath.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Are you having any of these symptoms when you're trying to sleep?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: uh yeah, I think its, yeah when I'm laying down sometimes I feel more short of breath than usual, but once I shift positions it goes back to it's normal.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Ok. Is it, do you ever have to wake up at night to catch a breath or anything like that?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Ah, no, it doesn't wake me up.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: And have you noticed any kind of, uh, significant weight loss or anything like that recently?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and have you at all had any changes in your appetite or anything like that?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, no change in appetite.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. Any exposures to any like dust, fumes or any irritants recently

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK And, in the past, have you been diagnosed with any medical conditions?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uhm,  just COPD, uhm, and, I also have some congestive heart failure.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and when were you diagnosed with both of them?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: COPD I've been, I got diagnosed about seven years ago, CHF about two years ago.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and uh, right now do you have any symptoms of any swelling in your extremities like legs, hands or anything like that?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Some swelling in, some swelling in my legs, yeah?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and do you have any kind of shortness of breath when you're lying down, at all?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, a little bit. Yeah, a little bit I would say.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. And any other medical conditions?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Nope, no others.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any allergies?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any medications you're on right now?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah I'm on, uh, an ACE inhibitor, I'm on, uh, Spironolactone, uhm, I'm on, I have some puffers for my COPD. I believe, what do I have, I have, um, I have a long acting beta agonist. And I guess I have a short acting as well for when I need it.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. And do you have, so is it just the two, two puffers?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Mhm.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and are you using, like the blue one, the blue one more at all, are you having to use the short acting one more?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I'm definitely using the short acting more, like I'm using it almost every day.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: And does it help at all?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh I4 think so.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK yeah, so other than that, are you on any other medications?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: No, OK. And have you been taking your Spironolactone?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, I've been taking all my medications.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, any previous hospitalizations or surgeries?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I was hospitalised two years ago for shortness of breath and some low oxygen, that's when they diagnosed me with CHF.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: I see OK and did they say at all, It was caused by, like your COPD or what was it caused by? Do you remember?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uhm,  I guess just, yeah, I'm not really too sure, they said I had some heart condition and my heart isn't functioning as well as it should be. They did an echo on me.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and have you at all had any kind of heart attacks or anything like that?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: No, OK. and did they, when you were having shortness of breath, did you have a like a pneumonia or infection that you had to get antibiotics for any or anything like that?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uhm, no. Actually I might have gotten some antibiotics at one point, but not during that visit.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. OK, And currently right now do you smoke?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, I stopped smoking two years ago.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yeah no, that's really good. And definitely with these symptoms and your condition that definitely helps to quit smoking whenever you can, so congratulations for that. Any alcohol at all?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I drink some alcohol. I drink maybe once a week.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and any recreational drugs like marijuana?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I smoke once in a while.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, how often would you say you smoke marijuana?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I smoke about a joint a week.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and uh, do you use a, like the provincial marijuana, or do you have any other source, what would you say you use?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I use uhm, Pardon me, what was that? Do I use?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Like uh, do you get it from a store that sells the joint?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, I get it from like a medical dispensary.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, OK, I see. Yeah, I just want to make sure because some, if you get it from other sources there might be more irritants in there that can cause some of your symptoms and for them to get worse as well. So yeah.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Oh I see, I see, OK.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yeah, and other than that, do you have any questions or concerns at all?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, what do you think I should do from, For now?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yeah, so right now what we're going to do is because you're having the coughing, shortness of breath, and you have a history of COPD & CHF, we definitely want to make sure that you're not having, uhm, what I think you might be having isn't just an exacerbation of your COPD, and especially with the green sputum it might be like a bacterial infection that's causing your symptoms to get worse, so we'll do all the appropriate testing, we'll do, a chest X-ray, we'll get some blood work done as well, w'ell give you some uh, Ventolin as well while you're here, and we might give you like a steroid medication as well. So we'll do some of those things right now for you to kind of help you right now, as well as do some of those tests that I mentioned. Depending on what comes back, you might require an admission to the hospital just because we want to make sure you don't go home with an exacerbation, especially with the CHF as well, we need to, we will need to get that under control because that can get worse with your COPD exacerbation as well. So we need to make sure some of that, swelling goes down, if we need to adjust your medications while you're here. So yeah, let's just, I'll get back to you, we'll do some of those testing and then see where to go from there. Is that OK?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, that sounds great. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Add differential diagnosis
